newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's Hashimoto says wants to remain premier.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Hashimoto says wants to remain premier.

text.p: Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said on Monday he wanted to stay on as prime minister as his party won the largest number of seats in Sunday's general election.
"I would like to continue to be in charge of the government as the leader of the party which has the largest number of seats in parliament," he told a news conference.
But Hashimoto also said that the polls, in which his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) failed to win a majority in parliament, showed that the electorate did not have full confidence in the party.
The LDP captured 239 seats in the 500-seat Lower House of parliament and Hashimoto was due to meet other members of the outgoing coalition later on Monday to try to form a new working majority.

Hashimoto said he favoured a continued coalition with the Social Democratic Party and the small Sakigake party, even though both parties saw a sharp fall in support. The Social Democrats now have 15 seats against 30 previously, while Sakigake has just two, compared with nine.
But Hashimoto also signalled a readiness to talk with the new Democratic Party, which captured 52 seats in the election.
